title: Vladimir Putin's Historical and Geopolitical Worldview
summary: Putin's worldview is shaped by the collapse of the Soviet Union (which he called 'the greatest geopolitical catastrophe of the 20th century'), Russian imperial history, and perception of Western attempts to weaken Russia. This framework informs his policies and rhetoric.

core_beliefs: Russia is a great power with natural sphere of influence in former Soviet space
Soviet collapse was historical injustice that separated Russian-speaking peoples
The West seeks to divide and weaken Russia
Strong centralized authority necessary for Russian survival
Western liberal democracy incompatible with Russian civilization
Multi-polar world preferable to US hegemony

frequently_cited: Kievan Rus (9th-13th century) - claims Russia-Ukraine historical unity
Russian Empire expansion - framed as gathering Russian lands
Great Patriotic War (WWII) - resistance against Western invasion
Soviet victory over Nazism - moral authority against fascism
Soviet collapse - humiliation and betrayal by West

key_quotes.speaker: Vladimir Putin
key_quotes.quote: The collapse of the Soviet Union was the greatest geopolitical catastrophe of the century. For the Russian people, it became a genuine tragedy. Tens of millions of our citizens and compatriots found themselves outside Russian territory.
key_quotes.context: Annual state of the nation address

key_quotes.speaker: Vladimir Putin
key_quotes.quote: Russians and Ukrainians are one people, a single whole. I am convinced that true sovereignty of Ukraine is possible only in partnership with Russia.
key_quotes.context: Essay 'On the Historical Unity of Russians and Ukrainians'

key_quotes.speaker: Vladimir Putin
key_quotes.quote: Modern Ukraine was entirely created by Russia, more precisely, by Bolshevik, communist Russia. This process began almost immediately after the 1917 revolution.

western_perspective.analysis: Western analysts characterize Putin's worldview as revanchist (seeking to reverse losses), imperialist (seeking to restore Russian empire), and zero-sum (any Western gain is Russian loss). Critics argue he romanticizes Russian imperial past while ignoring its oppressive aspects.
concerns: Denial of neighboring states' sovereignty and agency
Inability to accept post-Cold War order
Personalization of geopolitics (perceived slights to Russia as personal insults)

verified_claims: Putin served in KGB, including posting in East Germany during Soviet collapse
Putin became President/Prime Minister continuously since 1999 (24+ years in power)
Putin has consistently criticized Soviet collapse and Western actions since early 2000s
Putin published 5,000-word essay on Russian-Ukrainian unity in July 2021
key_policy_outcomes: Alignment with China against Western order

propaganda_techniques_observed: Strongman narrative (only Putin can restore Russian greatness)
Victimhood (Russia as perpetual victim of Western schemes)

sources.description: Putin's essay 'On the Historical Unity of Russians and Ukrainians'
Fiona Hill & Clifford Gaddy: 'Mr. Putin: Operative in the Kremlin'
